message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote on "(constitutive) character" format">
The author refines the format. Instead of "constitutive character" at first occurrence, use:

**(constitutive) character (德 De)**

The parentheses around "constitutive" visually signal that the qualifier is clarifying but will drop away. Then plain "character" in running text thereafter.

Compare:
- Option A: "constitutive character (德 De)" → then "character"
- Option B (author's proposal): "(constitutive) character (德 De)" → then "character"

The difference is subtle but Option B makes the shortening feel built-in from the start — the parentheses tell the reader "this word is here to help you, but it's not part of the term."

YES or NO? Brief response.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
NO, but I'll concede the battle on shortening since I'm clearly outvoted there. My concern remains: "character" alone is ambiguous in running text.

That said, if shortening is happening regardless, then Option B is worse than Option A. The parenthetical "(constitutive)" format is typographically awkward and philosophically self-undermining — it introduces a qualifier while simultaneously apologizing for it. It says "this word matters but also please ignore it." That's not how you establish a technical term.

If we must shorten: go with Option A. Introduce "constitutive character (德 De)" with full authority at first occurrence, explain in a TN that subsequent occurrences use "character" as shorthand, and let the reader do the work. At least that way the full term has dignity at introduction rather than arriving pre-deprecated.
input.summary: NO on Option B — if shortening, Option A is better

routing.summary: NO on Option B — if shortening, Option A is better

If we must shorten: go with Option A. content.text: Voted NO on Option B. If shortening to "character" is happening, Option A is the better path — introduce the full term with authority rather than the self-undermining parenthetical format that pre-deprecates the qualifier at the moment of introduction.
